address: 7511 St. Albans Road, 7433 St. Albans Road
description: The application is for the rezoning of 7511 St. Albans Road from 'Single Family Detached (RS1/E)' Zone to 'High Density Townhouse (RTH1)' Zone. The proposal is to permit the development of five three-storey townhouse units with vehicle access through an easement registered on Title of the adjacent property to the north at 7433 St. Albans Road. The site currently contains one single-family home, which will be demolished. The surrounding developments include a seven-unit, two-storey townhouse development to the North, a four-unit, three-storey townhouse development to the South, a 23-unit, three-storey townhouse development to the East, and a four-storey apartment building to the West. The proposed rezoning is subject to a community planning implementation strategy contribution for future community planning initiatives, a floodplain management implementation strategy, the City's Affordable Housing Strategy, and the Market Rental Housing Policy.

rawSummaries.summary:
RZ 18-818548
Application by Matthew Cheng Architect Inc. for Rezoning at 7511 St. Albans Road from 'Single Family Detached (RS1/E)' Zone to 'High Density Townhouse (RTH1)' Zone. The proposal is to permit the development of five three-storey townhouse units with vehicle access through an easement registered on Title of the adjacent property to the north at 7433 St. Albans Road. A preliminary site plan, building elevations and landscape plan are contained in Attachment 2. A Servicing Agreement will be required for this development to design and construct frontage beautification along St. Albans Road, relocation of an existing fire hydrant out of the proposed sidewalk and new service connections. The site currently contains one single-family home, which will be demolished. The rezoning application is subject to a community planning implementation strategy contribution for future community planning initiatives. The applicant proposes to make a cash contribution at the current rate of $0.34 per buildable square foot, for a total contribution of $2,264.40 prior to final adoption of the rezoning bylaw. The proposed redevelopment must meet the requirements of the Richmond Flood Plain Designation and Protection Bylaw 8204. Registration of a flood indemnity covenant on Title is required prior to final adoption of the rezoning bylaw. The City's Affordable Housing Strategy requires that all townhouse rezoning applications provide a cash-in-lieu contribution toward the City's Affordable Housing Reserve Fund. As per the Strategy, townhouse rezoning applications inside of the City Centre Area Plan are required to provide a cash-in-lieu contribution of $18.00 per buildable square foot. Consistent with the Strategy, a contribution of $119,880.00 is required prior to the final adoption of the rezoning bylaw. This rezoning application was received prior to the current Market Rental Housing Policy adopted by Council on June 20, 2022. In keeping with Council policy, instream rezoning applications are exempted from the Market Rental Housing Policy if the project reaches first reading no later than June 20, 2023.

The surrounding developments include a seven-unit, two-storey townhouse development to the North, a four-unit, three-storey townhouse development to the South, a 23-unit, three-storey townhouse development to the East, and a four-storey apartment building to the West. The proposed rezoning is subject to a community planning implementation strategy contribution for future community planning initiatives, a floodplain management implementation strategy, the City's Affordable Housing Strategy, and the Market Rental Housing Policy.

description: The development project involves the subdivision of the subject site into two half-acre residential lots. The proposed changes include a LAP Amendment from 'One Acre' to 'Half-acre Gross Density', a LAP Amendment from 'Suburban 1-Acre Residential (1 u.p.a)' to 'Suburban 1/2-Acre Residential (2 u.p.a)', and a Rezoning from RA to RH. Additionally, a Development Permit and Heritage Alteration Permit are being pursued. The project also includes modification and restoration of Semiahmoo Trail, as well as the introduction of a bylaw to rezone the subject site from 'One-Acre Residential Zone (RA)' to 'Half-Acre Residential Zone (RH)'. Furthermore, a bylaw amendment is being considered to redesignate the land from 'One Acre' to 'Half-acre Gross Density' in the Central Semiahmoo Peninsula Land Use Plan (LAP), and from 'Suburban 1-Acre Residential (1 u.p.a.)' to 'Suburban 1/2 -Acre Residential (2 u.p.a.)' in the King George Highway Corridor Local Area Plan (LAP).

The development does not mention specific dollar values or number/types of units.

description: The application is for a rezoning from RF to RF-13 and a Development Variance Permit to allow subdivision into two single family small lots with reduced lot depths and rear yard setbacks. The owners, J. Tandon and N. Tandon, are represented by the agent Westridge Engineering & Consulting Ltd. (Dave Kajal). The proposed development involves reducing the Type II minimum lot depth requirement of the RF-13 Zone from 24 metres to 22 metres for proposed Lots 1 & 2, reducing the rear yard setback requirement of the RF-13 Zone from 7.5 metres to 5.5 metres for proposed Lots 1 & 2, and varying the road width standard for a collector road from 24 metres to 16.5 metres for the fronting portion of Millar Road. The Council has instructed staff to resolve various issues prior to final adoption, including engineering requirements, tree replacement, Affordable Housing Strategy, and demolition of existing buildings and structures.

Agent: Westridge Engineering & Consulting Ltd. (Dave Kajal)
Rezoning from RF to RF-13

(a) to reduce the Type II minimum lot depth requirement of the RF-13 Zone from 24 metres to 22 metres for proposed Lots 1 & 2;

(a) ensure that all engineering requirements and issues including restrictive covenants, dedications, and rights-of -way where necessary, are addressed to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Engineering;

(c) the applicant satisfy the deficiency in tree replacement on the site, to the satisfaction of the Planning and Development Department;
(d) the applicant adequately address the City’s needs with respect to the City’s Affordable Housing Strategy, to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Planning & Development Services; and
(e) demolition of existing buildings and structures to the satisfaction of the Planning and Development Department.

The development permit is for the construction of a 3,797 square metre business park building. The final decision includes introducing a bylaw to amend the Official Community Plan (OCP) to permit a density up to 2.46 FAR within Block A, as well as rezoning a portion of the site to 'Comprehensive Development Zone (CD)' based on the 'Business Park 3 Zone (IB-3)'. The council has also authorized staff to draft Development Permit No. 7922-0051-00 and instructed staff to resolve various issues prior to final adoption.

description: The development in question involves a rezoning from RF to RM-30 and a TCP Amendment to amend the road network. The proposal is for the development of 34 townhouse units in Cloverdale Town Centre. The applicant is 1324074 B.C. Ltd. and the directors are Mayur Chirag Arora, Sachin Jhanghu, and Priya Janghu. The development also includes a Development Permit No. 7921-0301-00 and a Development Variance Permit. The Development Variance Permit includes various setbacks and parking space variations. The resolution also includes instructions for staff to resolve various issues related to engineering requirements, urban design, landscaping, tree preservation, demolition, and restrictive covenants. Additionally, there is a resolution to amend the Cloverdale Town Centre Plan for changes to the road network.

7921-0301-00

No Officer Information Filed as at September 13, 2022.

1267684 B.C. Ltd.

Sachin Jhanghu (Vice President)
Agent: S. Jhanghu
TCP Amendment to amend the road network
Rezoning from RF to RM-30
Development Permit / Development Variance Permit
to permit the development of 34 townhouse units in Cloverdale Town Centre.

It was Moved by Councillor Bose
Seconded by Councillor Stutt
That:

1. A Bylaw be introduced to rezone the subject site from "Single Family
Residential Zone (RF)" to "Multiple Residential 30 Zone (RM-30)" and a
date be set for Public Hearing.

2. Council authorize staff to draft Development Permit No. 7921-0301-00
generally in accordance with the attached drawings (Appendix I).

3. Council approve Development Variance Permit No. 7921-0301-00, varying
the following, to proceed to Public Notification:

(a) to reduce the minimum east street side yard setback of the RM-30 Zone
from 4.5 metres to 4.0 metres to the principal building face of
Buildings 1, 2 and 3;

(b) to reduce the minimum west side yard on a flanking lane setback of
the RM-30 Zone from 4.5 metres to 2.8 metres to the principal
building face of Buildings 4, 5, 6 and 7;

(c) to reduce the minimum north rear yard setback of the RM-30 Zone
from 6.0 metres to 4.5 metres to the principal building face of
Building 3; and

(d) to vary the RM-30 Zone to allow one (1) visitor parking space to be
within the required west side yard on a flanking lane on Building 6.

4. Council instruct staff to resolve the following issues prior to final adoption:

(a) ensure that all engineering requirements and issues including
restrictive covenants, dedications, and rights-of -way where necessary,
are addressed to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Engineering;

(b) submission of a subdivision layout to the satisfaction of the
Approving Officer;

(c) approval from the Ministry of Transportation & Infrastructure;

(d) resolution of all urban design issues to the satisfaction of the
Planning and Development Department;

(e) submission of a finalized landscaping plan and landscaping cost
estimate to the specifications and satisfaction of the Planning and
Development Department;

(f) submission of a finalized tree survey and a statement regarding tree
preservation to the satisfaction of the City Landscape Architect;

(g) the applicant satisfy the deficiency in tree replacement on the site,
to the satisfaction of the Planning and Development Department;

(h) demolition of existing buildings and structures to the satisfaction of
the Planning and Development Department;

(i) registration of a Section 219 Restrictive Covenant to specifically
identify the allowable tandem parking arrangement and to prohibit
the conversion of the tandem parking spaces into livable space; and

(j) registration of a Section 219 Restrictive Covenant to adequately
address the City’s needs with respect to public art, to the
satisfaction of the General Manager, Parks, Recreation and Culture
and with respect to the City’s Affordable Housing Strategy and
Tier 1 Capital Project CACs, to the satisfaction of the
General Manager, Planning & Development Services.

5. Council pass a resolution to amend the Cloverdale Town Centre Plan (TCP)
for changes to the road network when the project is considered for final
adoption (Appendix V).

behalf: 1089260 B C Ltd. (CIBT Education Group and Global Education City Holdings Inc.)
description: Urban Solutions Architecture Ltd., on behalf of the property owner, 1089260 B C Ltd. (CIBT Education Group and Global Education City Holdings Inc.), has applied to the City of Richmond for permission to rezone lands at 7780, 7800, 7804, 7820, and 7840 River Road from 'Auto-Oriented Commercial (CA)' to 'High Rise Riverfront Commercial (ZC49) – Aberdeen Village (City Centre)' to construct a high density commercial development along the Fraser River's Middle Arm. The development includes an 11-storey hotel, an 8-storey office building, retail and restaurant uses at grade, and underground parking. The total floor area is approximately 21,625 m² (232,769 ft²) comprising of hotel, retail/restaurant, and office space. The design and construction will meet Step 2 of the BC Energy Step Code, and there will be voluntary developer contributions towards public art and community amenities. Off-site works will be undertaken for dike upgrades and utility and road upgrades, as well as public realm improvements. Official Community Plan and City Centre Area Plan amendments are proposed to clarify the City's intent regarding dike improvements and to relocate park, road, pedestrian linkage, and commercial land use designations.

rawSummaries.summary:
RZ 17-788900
Urban Solutions Architecture Ltd. has applied to rezone lands at 7780, 7800, 7804, 7820 and 7840 River Road to construct a high density commercial development along the Fraser River's Middle Arm. The development includes an 11-storey hotel, an 8-storey office building, retail and restaurant uses, and underground parking. The total floor area is approximately 21,625 m². The design and construction will meet Step 2 of the BC Energy Step Code and include a low carbon energy plant. The developer will contribute towards public art and community amenities. Off-site works will be undertaken, including dike upgrades and utility and road upgrades. Official Community Plan and City Centre Area Plan amendments are proposed to clarify the City's intent and relocate park, road, pedestrian linkage and commercial land use designations.

The development includes an 11-storey hotel, an 8-storey office building, retail and restaurant uses at grade, and underground parking. The total floor area is approximately 21,625 m² (232,769 ft²) comprising of hotel, retail/restaurant, and office space. The design and construction will meet Step 2 of the BC Energy Step Code, and there will be voluntary developer contributions towards public art and community amenities. Off-site works will be undertaken for dike upgrades and utility and road upgrades, as well as public realm improvements. Official Community Plan and City Centre Area Plan amendments are proposed to clarify the City's intent regarding dike improvements and to relocate park, road, pedestrian linkage, and commercial land use designations.

Ltd., Inc.No. BC1108289, the registered owner of the lands located at 7688-7690 Cambie Street [PID 009-690-000; Lot 6 Block O District Lot 323 Plan 9322] and 7710-7720 Cambie Street [Strata Lots 1 and 2 District Lot 323 Strata Plan VR. 1090, Together with an Interest in the Common Property in Proportion to the Unit Entitlement of the Strata Lot as Shown on Form 1; PIDs 006-362-222 and 006-362-249, respectively]. description: The development is a multi-tenant industrial building located at 15238 - 64 Avenue. It also includes a restaurant and a volleyball facility. The development involves OCP Amendment from Agricultural to Industrial, Discharge of LUC No. 584, Rezoning from IL to CD, RGS amendment from Agricultural to Industrial, and ALR exclusion under Section 29 of the ALC Act. The final decision by the Council authorized staff to draft Development Permit No. 7922-0111-00 generally in accordance with the attached drawings, and the finalized Ecosystem Development Plan and geotechnical report. Various issues need to be resolved prior to final adoption, including engineering requirements, urban design issues, landscaping plan, tree survey, geotechnical report, Agricultural Land Reserve exclusion application, approval from Metro Vancouver for amendments to the Regional Growth Strategy and the Urban Containment Boundary, and registration of Section 219 Restrictive Covenants. Council also authorized staff to submit an exclusion application to the Agricultural Land Commission.

description: Gurjit Pooni has applied to rezone 8691 Heather Street from 'Single Detached (RS1/B)' zone to 'Single Detached (RS2/K)' zone to permit the property to be subdivided into two single-family lots. One lot will be accessed from Heather Street and the other from Dolphin Avenue. The existing tenant-occupied single-family dwelling on the subject property will be demolished. The proposed redevelopment will rezone and subdivide the existing single-family lot into two new single-family lots. Lot A will have access from Dolphin Avenue and Lot B (the corner lot) will have access from Heather Street. This is consistent with the lot fabric and vehicular access of neighboring lots. The applicant will be required to provide a landscape plan and register a restrictive covenant on Title to ensure the development's design is consistent with approved plans. Vehicle access to proposed Lot A will be from Dolphin Avenue and vehicle access to proposed Lot B will be from Heather Street. Sidewalks and landscaped boulevards are to be installed along both streets as part of a Servicing Agreement.

rawSummaries.summary:
RZ 21-940333 - 8691 Heather Street
Gurjit Pooni has applied to rezone 8691 Heather Street to permit the property to be subdivided into two single-family lots. One lot will be accessed from Heather Street and the other from Dolphin Avenue. The existing tenant-occupied single-family dwelling on the subject property will be demolished, and there are no existing secondary suites in the dwelling. The proposed rezoning and subdivision is consistent with the designation of 'Neighbourhood Residential' and 'Low Density Residential' in the Official Community Plan/Broadmoor Planning Area - Ash Street Sub Area Plan. No comments were received from the public regarding the rezoning application. The redevelopment proposes to rezone and subdivide the existing single-family lot into two new single-family lots with vehicular access from Dolphin Avenue and Heather Street. Current access is from Heather Street, with proposed access for Lot A from Dolphin Avenue and Lot B from Heather Street. Sidewalk and landscaped boulevard improvements will be made along both streets.

Vehicle access to proposed Lot A will be from Dolphin Avenue and vehicle access to proposed Lot B will be from Heather Street. description: Rav Bains has applied to rezone 8420 Heather Street from the 'Single Detached (RS1/B)' zone to the 'Single Detached (RS2/A)' zone, to permit the property to be subdivided into two equal-sized single family lots with secondary suites and vehicle access from Heather Street. The proposed subdivision plan is shown in Attachment 2. The existing single-family home on the property would be demolished, and there are no existing secondary suites present. The existing single-family home is currently renter occupied. The proposed rezoning and subdivision is consistent with the 'Neighbourhood Residential' designation in the Official Community Plan (OCP) and is located in the Broadmoor Planning Area and is designated for 'Low Density Residential' in the Broadmoor Area - Ash Street Sub-Area Plan. The proposed redevelopment must meet the requirements of the Richmond Flood Plain Designation and Protection Bylaw 8204. Vehicle access is proposed to be provided from Heather Street via separate driveway crossings to each new lot. At the subdivision stage, the applicant is required to pay a $29,200.00 cash-in-lieu contribution for the design and construction of frontage upgrades as well as the costs associated with the completion of the site servicing through a City Work Order.

rawSummaries.summary:
RZ 21-938262 - 8420 Heather Street
Rav Bains has applied to the City of Richmond to rezone 8420 Heather Street from 'Single Detached (RS1/B)' zone to 'Single Detached (RS2/A)' zone. The proposed redevelopment will rezone and subdivide the existing single-family lot into two new single-family lots with vehicular access from Heather Street. There is an existing 1.5 m Statutory Right-Of-Way (SRW) across the entire rear (east) property line for sanitary sewer. Vehicle access is proposed from Heather Street via separate driveway crossings to each new lot. The applicant is required to pay cash-in-lieu contribution for frontage upgrades and costs associated with site servicing, as well as taxes, Development Cost Charges, School Site Acquisition Charges, and Address Assignment Fees. Staff recommendation is to introduce and give first reading to Richmond Zoning Bylaw 8500, Amendment Bylaw 10435, for the rezoning of 8420 Heather Street from 'Residential Single Detached (RS1/B)' zone to 'Residential Single Detached (RS2/A)' zone.

The proposed redevelopment must meet the requirements of the Richmond Flood Plain Designation and Protection Bylaw 8204. Vehicle access is proposed to be provided from Heather Street via separate driveway crossings to each new lot. description: This report recommends rezoning the property at 691 West 28th Avenue from RS-1 District to RM-8A District to allow for a townhouse or rowhouse development. The property is located at the northeast corner of 28th Avenue and Heather Street, with an area of approximately 657 sq. m (7,072 sq. ft.) and a frontage of 17 m (57 ft.) along 28th Avenue. The Vancouver Plan and Cambie Corridor Plan guide the development of the area, supporting residential townhouses or rowhouses with a maximum FSR of 1.20. The subject site is located within the Queen Elizabeth neighbourhood, which calls for new townhouses in transition areas. The rezoning application implements Council-approved direction in the Plan and is supported by data and findings within the Housing Needs Report. The rezoning to RM-8A/AN follows a simplified process, with architectural drawings not required at the rezoning stage. The site is well served by public transit, including the King Edward Avenue Canada Line Station, and nearby bikeways provide sustainable transportation options. Parking, loading, and bicycle spaces are reviewed during the DP process, with upgrades required as per the Parking By-law.

description: The application is for the rezoning of 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue to CD-1 District. The proposal includes four buildings with residential and commercial uses. The subject site consists of 12 parcels with a total area of 6,346.5 sq. m. The existing zoning is RS-1, and the properties are currently developed with single-detached homes. The proposed rezoning is enabled through the Marpole Community Plan and allows for eight-storey, mixed-use buildings in subsection 6.3.1. The site is located on the southwest corner of Oak Street and West 64th Avenue, within the Oak Street sub-area of the Marpole Community Plan. The development is in the catchment area of David Lloyd George Elementary School and Sir Winston Churchill Secondary School. The Vancouver Plan and Marpole Community Plan guide the long-term growth of the City, and the proposal aligns with these plans. The site is also in close proximity to various amenities such as public parks, community spaces, and childcare facilities.

rawSummaries.summary:
CD-1 REZONING: 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue
Rezone 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue from RS-1 District to CD-1 District to allow for two residential buildings and two mixed-use buildings with 200 residential units. Proposed building height is 28.5 m and floor space ratio is 3.25. Applicant: Arno Matis Architecture. Referral: Report titled 'CD-1 Rezoning: 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue' dated December 20, 2022, referred to Public Hearing on January 17, 2023. Recommended Approval: By the General Manager of Planning, Urban Design and Sustainability, subject to conditions proposed for adoption by resolution of Council. A. Approve the application by Arno Matis Architecture on behalf of 1123197 B.C. Ltd. and 1119903 B.C. Ltd. to rezone the lands from RS-1 District to CD-1 District to increase FSR from 0.60 to 3.25 and building height from 10.7 m to 28.5 m, allowing for two residential buildings and two mixed-use buildings with a maximum height of eight storeys. B. Approve the application to amend the Sign By-law to establish regulations for the CD-1. C. Approve the application to amend the Noise Control By-law to include the CD-1. D. Approve the application to amend the Subdivision By-law. E. Adopt Recommendations A to D with specified conditions.

CD-1 Rezoning: 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue
This report evaluates an application to rezone 8029-8225 Oak Street and 1012 West 64th Avenue to CD-1 District. The proposal is to permit four buildings with residential and commercial uses. Staff recommend referring the application to a Public Hearing. The subject site is located on the southwest corner of Oak Street and West 64th Avenue. It consists of 12 parcels with a total site area of 6,346.5 sq. m. The existing zoning is RS-1 and the properties are currently developed with single-detached homes. The proposed rezoning is enabled through the Marpole Community Plan. The site is within the catchment area of David Lloyd George Elementary School and Sir Winston Churchill Secondary School. According to the Vancouver School Board's Long Range Facilities Plan, David Lloyd George will be operating below capacity. In the coming years, Churchill will operate at 111% capacity by 2031. The City coordinates with the VSB to inform decision-making and reduce enrolment pressure. VSB continues to monitor development and work with the City for future growth. Neighbourhood amenities include public parks (Oak Park, Eburne Park, Ebisu Park, and Ash Park), community spaces (Marpole Oakridge Community Centre and Marpole Neighbourhood House), and nine childcare facilities within 1 km of the site. The Vancouver Plan, approved by Council on July 22, 2022, guides the long-term growth of the City. The Marpole Community Plan aligns with the Vancouver Plan. The site is located within the Oak Street sub-area of the Marpole Community Plan, with two policy areas: subsections 6.3.1 and 6.3.2. Subsection 6.3.1 allows for eight-storey, mixed-use buildings.

The amendment would allow for a five-storey rental building in accordance with the Secured Rental Policy. A future building design would be submitted through the development permit process and reviewed with the public at that time. Staff recommend that the application be referred to a Public Hearing, with the recommendation of the General Manager of Planning, Urban Design and Sustainability to approve it in principle, subject to the Public Hearing, and conditions contained within Appendix B.

description: RGS Amendment from Industrial to General Urban, OCP Amendment from Industrial to Suburban, Rezoning from RA and IL to RC, Development Permit / Development Variance Permit to allow subdivision into 38 single family lots and two lots to be conveyed to the City for riparian, biodiversity and open space protection purposes. The development also includes various bylaws and permits for zoning changes, consultation with affected parties, and resolution of engineering, environmental, and planning issues.

rawSummaries.summary:
7916-0130-00
CIVIC ADDRESS: 11420 - 157A Street

APPLICANT: Owner: 1071948 B.C. Ltd.
(Director Information: Karl Schmidt, Donald Kent Sillars)
Agent: Pacific Land Resources Group Inc. (Oleg Verbenkov)

PURPOSE: The applicant is requesting an amendment to the Official Community Plan (OCP) Figure 3: General Land Use Designations to redesignate the site from Industrial to Suburban, and an amendment to Figure 42: Major Employment Areas by removing the Industrial designation for the subject site.

The proposal also includes rezoning a portion of the subject site from One-Acre Residential Zone to Cluster Residential Zone and a portion of the subject site from Light Impact Industrial Zone to Cluster Residential Zone in order to allow subdivision into 38 single family lots and two lots to be conveyed to the City for riparian, biodiversity and open space protection purposes.

In addition, the proposal includes a Development Variance Permit to reduce the minimum front yard setback from 7.5 metres to 6 metres to the principal building face for proposed Lots 8 to 22; and to reduce the minimum setback distance for a Class B (yellow-coded) watercourse from 15 metres, as measured from the top-of-bank, to a minimum of 55.3 metres as measured from the high water mark, which is equivalent to between 9.1 to 40.9 metres below top-of-bank.

7916-0130-00
Address: 11420 - 157A Street
Owner: 1071948 B.C. Ltd.
Director Information: Karl Schmidt, Donald Kent Sillars
Officer Information as at April 13, 2022: Donald Kent Sillars (President), Karl Schmidt (Secretary)
Agent: Pacific Land Resources Group Inc. (Oleg Verbenkov)
RGS Amendment from Industrial to General Urban
OCP Amendment from Industrial to Suburban
Rezoning from RA and IL to RC
Development Permit / Development Variance Permit to allow subdivision into 38 single family lots and two lots to be conveyed to the City for riparian, biodiversity and open space protection purposes.

It was Moved by Councillor Kooner
Seconded by Councillor Bains
That:
1. A Bylaw be introduced to:
(a) amend the Official Community Plan (OCP) Figure 3: General Land Use Designations for the subject site from Industrial to Suburban (Appendix VII), and a date for Public Hearing be set; and
(b) amend Official Community Plan (OCP) Figure 42: Major Employment Areas by removing the Industrial designation for the subject site (Appendix VIII), and a date for Public Hearing be set.
2. Council determine the opportunities for consultation with persons, organizations and authorities that are considered to be affected by the proposed amendment to the OCP, as described in the Report, to be appropriate to meet the requirement of Section 475 of the Local Government Act.
3. Council authorize staff to refer the application to Metro Vancouver Board for consideration and approval of a Type 3 Minor Amendment to the Regional Growth Strategy (RGS) designation of the subject site from Industrial to General Urban, following upon the application receiving Third Reading.
4. A Bylaw be introduced to rezone that portion the subject property shown as Block A on the Survey Plan attached as Appendix I from "One-Acre Residential Zone (RA)" to "Cluster Residential Zone (RC)" and that portion of the subject property shown as Block B on the Survey Plan attached Appendix I from "Light Impact Industrial Zone (IL)" to "Cluster Residential Zone (RC)" and a date be set for Public Hearing.
5. Council authorize staff to draft Development Permit No. 7916-0130-00 for Hazard Lands (Steep Slopes) and Sensitive Ecosystems (Streamside and Green Infrastructure Areas) generally in accordance with the finalized Geotechnical Report and Ecosystem Development and Mitigation Plan (Appendix VI).
6. Council approve Development Variance Permit No. 7916-0130-00, varying the following, to proceed to Public Notification:
(a) to reduce the minimum front yard setback of the RC Zone from 7.5 metres to 6 metres to the principal building face for proposed Lots 8 to 22; and
(b) to reduce the minimum setback distance for a Class B (yellow-coded) watercourse from 15 metres, as measured from the top-of-bank, to a minimum of 55.3 metres as measured from the high water mark, which is equivalent to between 9.1 to 40.9 metres below top-of-bank.
7. Council instruct staff to resolve the following issues prior to final adoption:
(a) ensure that all engineering requirements and issues including restrictive covenants, dedications, and rights-of-way where necessary, are addressed to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Engineering;
(b) submission of a subdivision layout to the satisfaction of the Approving Officer;
(c) approval from Metro Vancouver for a Type 3 Minor Regional Growth Strategy (RGS) amendment for the subject site from Industrial to General Urban;
(d) submission of a finalized tree survey and a statement regarding tree preservation to the satisfaction of the City Landscape Architect;
(e) the applicant satisfy the deficiency in tree replacement on the site, to the satisfaction of the Planning and Development Department;
(f) submission of a finalized Ecosystem Development Plan and Impact Mitigation Plan to the satisfaction of City staff, including provision of securities for proposed fencing, habitat planting and enhancement measures on Lots 10 to 22;
(g) registration of a combined Statutory Right-of-Way and Section 219 Restriction Covenant on proposed Lots 10-22 as per the "minimum safeguarding" requirements of the Sensitive Ecosystems Development Permit Area guidelines;
(h) conveyance of the proposed open space areas, containing both Streamside and Green Infrastructure Areas, to the City without compensation;
(i) submission of a finalized Geotechnical Report to the satisfaction of City staff;
(j) the applicant provide a density bonus amenity contribution consistent with the Tier 2 Capital Projects CACs in support of the requested increased density, to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Planning and Development Department;
(k) the applicant adequately address the City’s needs with respect to the City’s Affordable Housing Strategy, to the satisfaction of the General Manager, Planning & Development Services;
(l) submission of an acoustical report for the units adjacent to Highway 10 and the registration of Section 219 Restrictive Covenant to ensure the implementation of noise mitigation measures; and
(m) registration of a Section 219 Restrictive Covenant to ensure that future buildings, structures and site improvements comply with the accepted geotechnical recommendations on proposed Lots 1-38.

description: Rezoning from A-1 to CD and Development Permit for a dairy processing facility with an accessory farm market and eating establishment at 14159 - 40 Avenue (14269 - 40 Avenue). The council referred the non-farm use and soil use application to the Agricultural Land Commission (ALC) to allow for a farm retail market, a restaurant, and the placement of fill in excess of 1,000 square metres. A Bylaw will be introduced to rezone the subject site from 'General Agriculture Zone (A-1)' to 'Comprehensive Development Zone (CD)'. The applicant is required to obtain approval from the ALC for the proposed non-farm use and soil use prior to a Public Hearing being scheduled. Council also authorized staff to draft Development Permit No. 7920-0258-00 for Sensitive Ecosystems (Streamside Areas) and Hazard Lands (Flood Prone Areas) in accordance with the finalized Ecosystem Development Plan and Geotechnical Report. There are several issues that need to be resolved prior to final adoption, including engineering requirements, approval from the Ministry of Transportation & Infrastructure, landscaping plan, tree survey, Ecosystem Development Plan, Geotechnical Report, on-site fire protection, and registration of restrictive covenants and right-of-way to safeguard and maintain the environmental protection area.

description: The document pertains to the rezoning of 8460 Ash Street and 8495 Cambie Street. It discusses the approval of the rezoning in principle, subject to the owner of the lands entering into certain Housing Agreements with the City. It mentions the Original Housing Agreement for one lot within the development lands, and the subsequent replacement Housing Agreement to secure market rental housing instead of For-Profit Affordable Rental Housing. The document also refers to the enactment of the rezoning by-law under By-law No. 13475 and the registration of the New Housing Agreement at the Land Title Office under registration No. CB350890 to CB350891. The Director of Legal Services issued a statement on January 31, 2023, regarding the repeal of By-law No. 13361 authorizing the Original Housing Agreement.

rawSummaries.summary:
By-law No. 13361 - 8460 Ash Street and 8495 Cambie Street
On November 18 and 25, 2021, Public Hearings were held wherein a rezoning of 8460 Ash Street and 8495 Cambie Street was approved in principle, subject to the owner of the lands entering into certain Housing Agreements with the City. Subsequently, the land owner and the City entered into a Housing Agreement (the “Original Housing Agreement”) for one lot that is within the development lands, being the lot legally described as Lot A Block 7 District Lot 311 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan EPP115039, as approved under By-law No. 13361 and thereafter the rezoning by-law was enacted on July 20, 2022 under By-law No. 13475 (the “Rezoning By-law”). The land owner subsequently elected not to pursue a DCL waiver and accordingly, requested that the Original Housing Agreement be amended or replaced to secure market rental housing instead of For-Profit Affordable Rental Housing. As such, the land owner and the City entered into a replacement Housing Agreement (the “New Housing Agreement”), as authorized under By-law No. 13573, the New Housing Agreement was registered at the Land Title Office under registration No. CB350890 to CB350891. The Original Housing Agreement was replaced by the New Housing Agreement and accordingly, By-law No. 13361, authorizing the Original Housing Agreement should be repealed. Director of Legal Services January 31, 2023

description: The application is for the rezoning of the properties at 6151-6261 Granville Street and 1511 West 47th Avenue for the development of a Community Care Facility – Class B for seniors. The site is located at the northwest corner of Granville Street and 47th Avenue in the Shaughnessy neighborhood. The site consists of seven parcels with detached houses and is currently regulated by the RS-3 District Schedule. The proposed development is a Community Care Facility - Class B for residential care for seven or more persons not related by blood or marriage. The surrounding area contains detached residential housing, parks, community centers, and commercial nodes. The Vancouver Plan, approved by Council, is a long-term growth strategy for the next 30 years and supports rezonings for institutional uses and seniors housing. The Secured Rental Policy encourages new purpose-built rental housing, with locational eligibility criteria for sites in low-density areas.

rawSummaries.summary:
CD-1 Rezoning: 6151-6261 Granville Street and 1511 West 47th Avenue - RTS 15458
This report evaluates an application to rezone the properties at 6151-6261 Granville Street and 1511 West 47th Avenue for the development of a Community Care Facility – Class B for seniors. Staff support the application, subject to conditions, and recommend referring it to a public hearing with the recommendation to approve it in principle. The subject site is located at the northwest corner of Granville Street and 47th Avenue in the Shaughnessy neighborhood. The site consists of seven parcels with detached houses. The site is currently regulated by the RS-3 District Schedule. The surrounding properties are zoned RS-1 and RS-3 and contain detached residential housing. Montgomery Park is approximately 750 m away. Kerrisdale Community Centre, Ryerson United Church, and the Jewish Community Centre are approximately 1.5 km away. Trinity Baptist Church Day Care, Osler YMCA Kids Club, and Maple Grove YMCA Kids Club are all within 750 m. A small commercial node is located approximately 500 m to the north at the intersection of Granville Street and 41st Avenue. The Kerrisdale Village shopping area is approximately 1.5 km to the northwest. A local bus stop is located on the subject block and the rapid bus is located on 41st Avenue. The Vancouver Plan approved by Council on July 22, 2022, is a land use strategy for long-term growth over the next 30 years. Vancouver Plan will serve as a framework with further implementation planning work to follow in the next 2-4 years. Site located in Arbutus Ridge, Kerrisdale, and Shaughnessy Vision. Implementation includes a review of existing land use policies and expanding opportunities. ARKS Vision supports rezonings for institutional uses and seniors housing. ARKS Vision suggests "small developments" for seniors near parks, shopping, transit, and services. Community Care Facility - Class B and Group Residence Guidelines define a "Community Care Facility - Class B" as residential care for seven or more persons not related by blood or marriage. Guidelines specify locational criteria and design considerations for community care facilities. Secured Rental Policy encourages new purpose-built rental housing. Updates approved in December 2021 to streamline delivery of new rental housing. SRP outlines locational eligibility criteria for sites in low-density areas.

description: The development project involves the rezoning of the subject site from 'One-Acre Residential Zone (RA)' to 'Quarter Acre Residential Zone (RQ)'. It also includes an NCP Amendment from 'Existing One Acre & Half Acre Lots' to 'Single Detached (3-4 u.p.a.)'. The proposed development will allow for subdivision into four single family lots, with a variance to reduce the minimum lot width of the RQ Zone for proposed Lots 3 and 4. Additionally, the project includes the drafting of Development Permit No. 7922-0233-00 for Sensitive Ecosystems (Streamside Areas) and the approval of Development Variance Permit No. 7922-0233-00. The development plan also involves various issues to be resolved prior to final adoption, including engineering requirements, tree preservation, tree replacement, lot grading plan, ecosystem development plan, density bonus amenity contribution, and affordable housing strategy. Furthermore, there will be a resolution to redesignate the subject site from 'Existing One Acre & Half Acre Lots' to 'Single Detached (3-4 u.p.a.)' in the North Grandview Heights Neighbourhood Concept Plan (NCP) when the project is considered for final adoption.

description: The applicant is requesting to rezone the subject site from One-Acre Residential Zone to Half-Acre Residential Zone in order to allow subdivision into two single-family residential lots. The proposal has received opposition from numerous individuals and groups citing concerns about tree removal, safety, and proximity to schools. The agent on behalf of the applicant provided an overview of the proposal, community support, infrastructure related to development, and tree retention and removal. Written submissions expressing opposition were received from various members of the community, as well as concerns expressed during the Public Hearing.

CIVIC ADDRESS: 3250 - 144 Street

Agent: CitiWest Consulting Ltd. (Jasleen Kaur)

PURPOSE: The applicant is requesting to rezone the subject site from One-Acre Residential Zone to Half-Acre Residential Zone in order to allow subdivision into two single-family residential lots.

The Notice of the Public Hearing was read by the City Clerk.

R. Landale, Fleetwood: The delegation spoke to tree retention, maintenance and removal, and Green City fund contributions.

description: The applicant, 1275280 B.C. Ltd., is requesting to rezone the subject site from Single Family Residential Zone to Comprehensive Development Zone in order to permit the development of a 6-storey rental apartment building consisting of 60 dwelling units in City Centre. The proposed development is located at 13412 - 96 Avenue, 13414 - 96 Avenue, and 13420 - 96 Avenue. The agent for the applicant is Flat Architecture Inc. The development has received opposition from residents and written submissions citing concerns about tree removal, Green City Fund contribution, traffic, greenspace, and impacts on birds and wildlife.

PURPOSE: The applicant is requesting to rezone the subject site from Single Family Residential Zone to Comprehensive Development Zone in order to permit the development of a 6-storey rental apartment building consisting of 60 dwelling units in City Centre.

R. Landale, Fleetwood: The delegation spoke to tree removal, Green City Fund contribution, and traffic.

Resident, Surrey: The delegation spoke to greenspace, tree removal and impacts on birds and wildlife.

• Z. Zhou expressing opposition for the proposal.

address: 12823 No. 10 (58 Avenue) Highway, 12841 No. 10 (58 Avenue) Highway
description: The applicant, Parkland Corporation, is requesting to rezone a portion of the subject site at 12841 No. 10 (58 Avenue) Highway, and the subject site at 12823 No. 10 (58 Avenue) Highway from Local Commercial Zone and Combined Service Gasoline Station Zone to Comprehensive Development Zone. This is in order to facilitate a lot line adjustment and development of electric vehicle charging stations and to reflect the existing uses on the site. The proposal has received opposition from R. Landale, citing lack of information available for the application, as well as concerns about trees and developmental transparency.
